owl:AnnotationProperty.obo:IAO_0000115: The official OBI definition, explaining the meaning of a class or property. Shall be Aristotelian, formalized and normalized. Can be augmented with colloquial definitions.
The official definition, explaining the meaning of a class or property. Shall be Aristotelian, formalized and normalized. Can be augmented with colloquial definitions.
owl:AnnotationProperty.rdfs:label: definition
definition
textual definition

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: dislikes
owl:ObjectProperty.skos:definition: something that a person habitually does not like or enjoy, a feeling of aversion or disapproval

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: forbids
owl:ObjectProperty.skos:definition: to hinder or prevent as if by an effectual command

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: has flavor
owl:ObjectProperty.skos:definition: indicates that this item has this flavor

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: has ingredient
owl:ObjectProperty.skos:definition: to have a component part of any combination or mixture

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: has saved
owl:ObjectProperty.skos:definition: to store (data) in a computer or on a storage device

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: has texture
owl:ObjectProperty.skos:definition: indicates that this item has this texture

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: is allergic to
owl:ObjectProperty.skos:definition: the subject has an allergy to the object of this relation

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: is recommended for course
owl:ObjectProperty.skos:definition: a property of recipe that indicates what course the recipe is recommended for

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: is recommended for meal
owl:ObjectProperty.skos:definition: a property of recipe that indicates what meal the recipe is recommended for

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: substitutes for
owl:ObjectProperty.skos:definition: indicates that this item can take the place or function of another

owl:ObjectProperty.dc:description: a addresses b if a provides an answer to b
owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: addresses

owl:ObjectProperty.dc:description: a property between a creator and the question that the creator poses
owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: asks

owl:ObjectProperty.dc:description: a property that associates a person entity with the object they consume
owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: is consumer of

owl:ObjectProperty.dc:description: a property that captures what form of output an entity a is presented in
owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: has preference for

owl:ObjectProperty.dc:description: a property that captures what form of output an entity a is presented in
owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: has presentation

owl:ObjectProperty.dc:description: a property that associates a process with an object/informational content entity that it addresses
owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: implements

owl:ObjectProperty.dc:description: maps a property with its associated object
owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: possess

owl:DatatypeProperty.rdfs:label: has cook time
owl:DatatypeProperty.skos:definition: the time that something needs to cook

owl:DatatypeProperty.rdfs:label: has cooking temperature
owl:DatatypeProperty.skos:definition: the temperature at which a food must be baked

owl:DatatypeProperty.rdfs:label: has gluten
owl:DatatypeProperty.skos:definition: a property of ingredients that show whether or not that ingerdient contains gluten

owl:DatatypeProperty.terms:source: Méthod Montignac , "The Glycemic Index Concept," 2014. [Online]. Available: http://www.montignac.com/en/the-glycemic-index-concept/. [Accessed Nov. 1 2018]
owl:DatatypeProperty.rdfs:label: has glycemic index
owl:DatatypeProperty.skos:definition: has a glycemic indexe value which measures carbs’ from the perspective of their pure sugar/starch content in order to determine how they affect glycemia (blood sugar levels) after meals

owl:DatatypeProperty.terms:source: "Serve definition and meaning," Collins English Dictionary. Available: https://www.collinsdictionary.com/dictionary/english/serve [Accessed 27-Oct-2018].
owl:DatatypeProperty.rdfs:label: serves
owl:DatatypeProperty.skos:definition: used to indicate how much food a recipe produces

rdf:Description.terms:source: Chari, S., Gruen, D. M., Seneviratne, O., & McGuinness, D. L. (2020). Foundations of Explainable Knowledge-Enabled Systems. arXiv preprint arXiv:2003.07520.
rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Explanation
rdf:Description.skos:definition: an account of the system, its workings, the implicit and explicit knowledge used in its reasoning processes and the specific decision, that is sensitive to the end-user's understanding, context, and current needs

owl:Class.rdfs:label: breakfast recipe
owl:Class.skos:definition: a class that contains recipes of type breakfast

owl:Class.rdfs:label: characteristic
owl:Class.skos:definition: a distinguishing trait, quality, or property
owl:Class.skos:example: Classes that inherit from this class represent different possible characteristics of food. Examples in this ontology include "flavor" and "texture" but these can be expanded as desired. Specific flavors and textures are represented as individuals that inherent from their respective subclass.

owl:Class.rdfs:label: chemical food product
owl:Class.skos:definition: a food substance derived from a nonliving source (e.g., salt, water or synthesized compounds)

owl:Class.rdfs:label: course
owl:Class.skos:definition: dfferent types of specific sets of food items that are served together during a meal
owl:Class.skos:example: The individuals that inhreit from this class represent courses of a meal. The recipe "banana bread" can be "recommended for course" "dessert". Additional courses can be added as individuals that inheret from this class.

owl:Class.rdfs:label: dinner recipe
owl:Class.skos:definition: a class that contains recipes of type dinner

owl:Class.rdfs:label: flavor
owl:Class.skos:definition: the quality of something that affects the sense of taste

owl:Class.terms:source: BBC, "Food Ontology," ONTOLOGIES, March 2014. [Online]. Available: https://www.bbc.co.uk/ontologies/fo. [Accessed Sep. 29, 2018].
owl:Class.rdfs:label: food
owl:Class.skos:definition: something that can be eaten
owl:Class.skos:example: This class is the top-level element that represents different classifications of food. An ingredient individual will have the type of the most specific category it falls under. For example, "chicken egg" will be a type of "egg" which is a subclass of "poultry product" which is a subclass of "primary food commodity of animal origin" which is a subclass of "food". Additional classifications can be added at any level of the classification.

owl:Class.rdfs:label: ingredient
owl:Class.skos:definition: a food that is used with other foods in the preparation of a particular dish
owl:Class.skos:example: Individuals that are subclasses of this class represent ingredients that are used in a specific recipe. For example, the individual "banana" is a subclass of "ingredient" and the recipe "banana bread" "has ingredient" "banana". Ingredients can have the properties "has glycymic index" and "has gluten".

owl:Class.rdfs:label: less than one hour recipe
owl:Class.skos:definition: a class that contains all recipes that only take one hour to cook

owl:Class.rdfs:label: lunch recipe
owl:Class.skos:definition: a class that contains recipes of type lunch

owl:Class.rdfs:label: meal
owl:Class.skos:definition: a class that links a recipe to a certain meal
owl:Class.skos:example: The individuals that inhreit from this class represent different types of meals. The recipe "kamut pancakes" can be "recommended for meal" "breakfast". Additional meals can be added as individuals that inheret from this class.

owl:Class.rdfs:label: measurement
owl:Class.skos:definition: an adequate or due portion
owl:Class.skos:example: This class contains subclasses that represent different kinds of measurements relating to cooking. For example "time measurement" is a class that contains the individuals "minute" and "hour" and is used to represent the amount of time a recipe takes to make or cook.

owl:Class.rdfs:label: meat from chicken
owl:Class.skos:definition: the muscular tissues from a chicken

owl:Class.rdfs:label: meat from cow
owl:Class.skos:definition: the muscular tissues from a cow

owl:Class.rdfs:label: meat from lamb
owl:Class.skos:definition: the muscular tissues from a lamb

owl:Class.rdfs:label: meat from pig
owl:Class.skos:definition: the muscular tissues from a pig

owl:Class.rdfs:label: milk from cow
owl:Class.skos:definition: milk obtained from a cow

owl:Class.rdfs:label: mushroom
owl:Class.skos:definition: the fleshy, spore-bearing fruiting body of a fungus, typically produced above ground on soil or on its food source

owl:Class.terms:source: NHS, "Eating processed foods," January 2017. [Online]. Available: https://www.nhs.uk/live-well/eat-well/what-are-processed-foods/. [Accessed Nov.22 2018]
owl:Class.rdfs:label: primary food commodity of fungus origin
owl:Class.skos:definition: unaltered food derived from fungus

owl:Class.terms:source: BBC, "Food Ontology," ONTOLOGIES, March 2014. [Online]. Available: https://www.bbc.co.uk/ontologies/fo. [Accessed Sep. 29, 2018].
owl:Class.rdfs:label: recipe
owl:Class.skos:definition: a combination of ingredients and a method, created by a chef, that produces a food
owl:Class.skos:example: Individuals that are a type of this class represent instances of recipes that are found online. For example, the individual "banana bread" can be found on AllRecipes.com and has the properties "has ingredient," "has cook time," "has cooking temprature," "serves," "is recommended for course," and "is recommended for meal".

owl:Class.rdfs:label: side recipe
owl:Class.skos:definition: a class that contains recipes of type side

owl:Class.rdfs:label: temperature measurement
owl:Class.skos:definition: degree of hotness or coldness measured on a definite scale

owl:Class.rdfs:label: texture
owl:Class.skos:definition: the characteristic physical structure given to a material, an object, etc., by the size, shape, arrangement, and proportions of its parts

owl:Class.rdfs:label: time measurement
owl:Class.skos:definition: the measured or measurable period during which an action, process, or condition exists or continues

owl:Class.rdfs:label: user
owl:Class.skos:definition: a user of the system
owl:Class.skos:example: Individuals that inherit from this class represent users of the system. Individual users can have likes, dislikes, and allergies that are saved in the system through the "likes," "dislikes," "forbids," and "is allergic to," properties.

owl:Class.rdfs:label: yeast
owl:Class.skos:definition: humid, yellowish froth produced by fermenting malt worts, and used to brew beer, leaven bread, and also used in certain medicines

owl:Class.terms:source: Montignac Method, "Search for a specific Glycemic Index," 2014. [Online]. Available: http://www.montignac.com/en/search-for-a-specific-glycemic-index/. [Accessed Nov. 1, 2018]
owl:Class.rdfs:label: high glycemic recipe
owl:Class.skos:definition: a class of recipes that contains an ingredient with a glycemic index of 50 or more

owl:Class.dc:description: is an activity that uses a reasoning type to accomplish within a defined period of time a goal within a larger problem
owl:Class.terms:source: Tu, S. W., Eriksson, H., Gennari, J. H., Shahar, Y., & Musen, M. A. (1995). Ontology-based configuration of problem-solving methods and generation of knowledge-acquisition tools: application of PROTEGE-II to protocol-based decision support. Artificial intelligence in medicine, 7(3), 257-289.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: AI Task
owl:Class.skos:example: Deductive task

owl:Class.dc:description: Abduction is a task which tries to identify those initial conditions which deduction starts from, given general laws and some singular statements called final states.
owl:Class.terms:source: Stefanelli, M., & Ramoni, M. (1992). Epistemological constraints on medical knowledge-based systems. In Advanced models of cognition for medical training and practice (pp. 3-20). Springer, Berlin, Heidelberg.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Abductive Task

owl:Class.dc:description: a subroutine that implements a single family of AI models and takes as input certain inputs and outputs a value
owl:Class.rdfs:label: AI Method

owl:Class.terms:description: Case-based explanations contain results that “are based on actual prior cases that can be presented to the user to provide compelling support for the system’s conclusions” (Cunningham et al., 2003). Borrowing from Leake, 1988 and Ahmed, 2015, we opine that an AI system generating case-based explanations needs to remember and adapt explanations of similar prior cases (Leake, 1988), or, “has to reason from experiences (old cases) in an effort to solve problems, critique solutions and explain anomalous situation” (Ahmed, 2015). Case-based explanations can involve analogical reasoning, relying on similarities between features of the case and of the current situation.
owl:Class.terms:source: Ahmed IM, Alfonse M, Aref M, Salem ABM. Reasoning Techniques for Diabetics Expert Systems. Procedia Computer Science. 2015;65:813–820
Cunningham P, Doyle D, Loughrey J. An evaluation of the usefulness of case-based explanation. In: International Conference on Case-Based Reasoning. Springer; 2003. p. 122–130.
Leake DB. Evaluating Explanations. In: AAAI; 1988. p. 251–255
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Case Based Explanation
owl:Class.skos:definition: Provides solutions that are based on actual prior cases that can be presented to the user to provide compelling support for the system’s conclusions, and may involve analogical reasoning, relying on similarities between features of the case and of the current situation.
owl:Class.skos:example: Addresses question of the form, "To what other situations has this recommendation been applied?"

owl:Class.terms:source: Lorin, M.I., Palazzi, D.L., Turner, T.L., Ward, M.A.: What is a clinical pearl andwhat is its role in medical education? Medical teacher30(9-10), 870–874 (2008)
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Clinical Pearls
owl:Class.skos:definition: small bits of free-standing, clinically relevant information based on experience or observation
owl:Class.skos:example: Addresses a question of the form, "What is a fact a system should consider when prescribing this medication?"

owl:Class.dc:description: Contextual explanations are those that refer to information about items other than the explicit inputs and output, such as information about the user, situation, and broader environment that affected the computation. Providing such information requires that a system be “context-aware,” and can include information about a “user’s tasks, significant user attributes, organizational environment, and technical and physical environments” (I.O. for standardization).
owl:Class.terms:source: I. O. for Standardization, Human-centred design processes for interactive systems. Int. Organization for Standardization, 1999
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Contextual Explanation
owl:Class.skos:definition: Refers to information about items other than the explicit inputs and output, such as information about the user, situation, and broader environment that affected the computation.
owl:Class.skos:example: Addresses a question of the form, "What broader information about the current situation prompted the suggestion of this recommendation?"

owl:Class.terms:description: Contextual knowledge is all the knowledge that is relevant and can be mobilized to understand a given situated decision problem. By "situated" we mean in given, dated, well specified circumstances (Clancey 1991). Contextual knowledge is evoked by situations and events, and loosely tied to a task or a goal. However, when the task becomes more precise (e.g., an event occurs), a large part of this contextual knowledge can be proceduralized according to the current focus of the decision making.
owl:Class.terms:source: Brézillon, P., & Pomerol, J. C. (1999, July). Contextual knowledge and proceduralized context. In Proceedings of the AAAI-99 Workshop on Modeling Context in AI Applications, Orlando, Florida, USA, July. AAAI Technical Report.
Dey, A. K. (2001). Understanding and using context. Personal and ubiquitous computing, 5(1), 4-7.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Contextual Knowledge
owl:Class.skos:definition: all the knowledge that is relevant and can be mobilized to understand a given situated decision problem.

owl:Class.dc:description: As described by (Van der Waa, 2018) and (Miller, 2019), contrastive explanations define an output of interest and present contrasts between the fact (the event that did occur), the given output, and the foil (the event that did not occur), the output of interest.
owl:Class.terms:source: J. van der Waa, M. Robeer, J. van Diggelen, M. Brinkhuis, and M. Neerincx, “Contrastive explanations with local foil trees,” arXiv preprint arXiv:1806.07470, 2018.
T. Miller, “Explanation in artificial intelligence: Insights from the social sciences,” Artificial Intelligence, vol. 267, pp. 1–38, 2019
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Contrastive Explanation
owl:Class.skos:definition: Answers the question “Why this output instead of that output,” making a contrast between the given output and the facts that led to it (inputs and other considerations), and an alternate output of interest and the foil (facts that would have led to it).
owl:Class.skos:example: Addresses a question of the form, "Why administer this new drug over the one I would typically prescribe?"

owl:Class.rdfs:label: Counterfactual Explanation
owl:Class.skos:definition: Addresses the question of what solutions would have been obtained with a different set of inputs than those used.
owl:Class.skos:example: Addresses a question of the form, "What if the patient had a high risk for cardiovascular disease? Would you still recommend the same treatment plan?"

owl:Class.rdfs:label: Decision Tree
owl:Class.skos:definition: is a decision support tool that uses a tree-like model of decisions and their possible consequences, including chance event outcomes, resource costs, and utility. It is one way to display an algorithm that only contains conditional control statements.

owl:Class.dc:description: Deduction allows us to derive from each candidate hypothesis what one expects to be true (consequence) if that hypothesis is true
owl:Class.terms:source: Stefanelli, M., & Ramoni, M. (1992). Epistemological constraints on medical knowledge-based systems. In Advanced models of cognition for medical training and practice (pp. 3-20). Springer, Berlin, Heidelberg.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Deductive Task

owl:Class.dc:description: deals with the physical aspects of the experimental situation
owl:Class.terms:source: Smith, S. M., Glenberg, A., & Bjork, R. A. (1978). Environmental context and human memory. Memory & Cognition, 6(4), 342-353.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Environmental Context

owl:Class.dc:description: Accounts of the real world that appeal to the user based on their general understanding and knowledge [(McNeil and Krajack, 2008) of how the world works, and that help them understand why particular facts (events, properties, decisions, etc.) occurred (Miller, 2019).
owl:Class.terms:source: K. L. McNeill and J. Krajcik, “Inquiry and scientific explanations: Helping students use evidence and reasoning,” Sci. as inquiry in the secondary setting, pp. 121–134, 2008
T. Miller, “Explanation in artificial intelligence: Insights from the social sciences,” Artificial Intelligence, vol. 267, pp. 1–38, 2019.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Everyday Explanation
owl:Class.skos:definition: Uses accounts of the real world that appeal to the user, given their general understanding and knowledge.
owl:Class.skos:example: Addresses a question of the form, "Why are gloves recommended when dealing with high-risk patients?"
Addresses a question of the form, "Why does option A make sense?"

owl:Class.dc:description: account that articulates how or why an event occured that is supported by evidence and scientific ideas
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Evidence Based Explanation
owl:Class.skos:example: Address questions of the form, "What studies support this recommendation?"

owl:Class.rdfs:label: Experential Knowledge
owl:Class.skos:definition: information and wisdom gained from lived experience

owl:Class.dc:description: the impact that an explanation has on a user or the purpose it was designed to achieve
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Explanation Goal
owl:Class.skos:example: educational

owl:Class.dc:description: a particular form/media in which an explanation exists is expressed
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Explanation Modality

owl:Class.dc:description: inputs and other considerations that led to a system recommendation that did occur
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Fact

owl:Class.dc:description: facts that would have led to a system recommendation that could have occured
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Foil

owl:Class.dc:description: Induction is able to match single statement to single statement and, therefore, to match a single statement derived as a prediction from a hypothesis with a single statement describing a portion of the real state of airs in the patient.
owl:Class.terms:source: Stefanelli, M., & Ramoni, M. (1992). Epistemological constraints on medical knowledge-based systems. In Advanced models of cognition for medical training and practice (pp. 3-20). Springer, Berlin, Heidelberg.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Inductive Task

owl:Class.dc:description: a mechanistic explanation involves presenting a model of the mechanism (the explanans) responsible for some phenomenon of interest (the explanandum). A mechanism is an entity or structure, such as an organ (though a mechanism need not be delineated by such clear physical boundaries) that performs a function by virtue of its component parts, operations and, importantly, their spatial and temporal organisation (Bechtel & Abrahamsen 2005: 421–23). That is, a mechanism does not just consist in its physical parts, but in the ‘organised interplay’ of the activities of those parts (Soom 2012: 656). Examples of phenomena (i.e.,functions or behaviours performed by mechanisms) include such things as the heart’s pumping blood, metabolism and memory.
owl:Class.terms:source: Dessaix, D. Mechanistic Explanation: Some Limits and their Significance. The ANU Undergraduate Research Journal, 51.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Mechanistic Explanation
owl:Class.skos:example: Addresses a question of the form, "What is a biological basis for this recommendation?"

owl:Class.dc:description: a statistical value that backs and quantifies a recommendation
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Numerical Evidence

owl:Class.dc:description: a process being executed by the system that achieves a particular goal; e.g. inference models such as treatment planning involved in medical diagnosis can be considered reasoning modes where system is executing a set of tasks
owl:Class.terms:source: Ramoni, M., Stefanelli, M., Magnani, L., & Barosi, G. (1992). An epistemological framework for medical knowledge-based systems. IEEE Transactions on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics, 22(6), 1361-1375.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Reasoning Mode
owl:Class.skos:example:
The treatment planning process proceeds in four steps. First, the play therapist must develop accurate, comprehensive treatment goals that are consistent with the case formulation and the theoretical model being used. Because these goals are formulated from a theoretical perspective, they may not fully align with the goals of the child and his or her caregivers. Therefore, in the second step, the play therapist must work with both the child client and his or her caregivers to develop a treatment contract that takes the goals created in the first step and addresses each party’s needs. This will ensure they will remain actively engaged in the treatment process over time. Third, the play therapist must organize the treatment goals and the treatment contracts into a realistic and sequential treatment plan. Finally, the play therapist must devise both experiential and cognitive/verbal interventions to move the client toward the treatment goals.
Source: O'Connor, K. J., & Ammen, S. (2012). Play therapy treatment planning and interventions: The ecosystemic model and workbook. Academic Press.

owl:Class.rdfs:label: Scientific Knowledge
owl:Class.skos:definition: knowledge accumulated by systematic study and organized by general principles

owl:Class.dc:description: involves a question and suggested explanation (hypothesis) based on observation, followed by the careful design and execution of controlled experiments, and finally validation, refinement or rejection of this hypothesis.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Scientific Method

owl:Class.terms:description: Simulation-based explanations are those based on an imagined or implemented imitation of a system or process and the results that emerge from similar inputs. As simulations can often be run numerous times (e.g. Monte Carlo simulations), and the mechanisms in the simulation can often be observed and traced directly, simulation-based explanations can have elements of statistical and trace-based explanations. Heal suggests that these explanations (Heals, 1996) contain facts that humans would use to determine an outcome in a specified case, and these explanations are intended to “replace and amplify real experiences with guided ones, often “immersive” in nature, that evoke or replicate substantial aspects of the real world in a fully interactive fashion” (Lateef, 2010)
owl:Class.terms:source: F. Lateef, “Simulation-based learning: Just like the real thing,” J. of Emergencies, Trauma and Shock, vol. 3, no. 4, p. 348, 2010
J. Heal, “Simulation, theory, and content,” Theories of theories of mind, pp. 75–89, 1996.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Simulation Based Explanation
owl:Class.skos:definition: Uses an imagined or implemented imitation of a system or process and the results that emerge from similar inputs
owl:Class.skos:example: Addresses a question of the form, "What would happen if this recommendation is followed?"

owl:Class.terms:description: Statistical explanations present an account of the outcome based on data about the occurrence of events under specified (e.g., experimental) conditions. Statistical explanations refer to numerical evidence on the likelihood of factors or processes influencing the result. (Hempel, 1962) add that a particularly high probability allows the outcome to be expected with practical certainty in any one case where the specified conditions occur.
owl:Class.terms:source: C. G. Hempel, “Deductive-nomological vs. statistical explanation,” University of Minnesota Press, Minneapolis, 1962.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Statistical Explanation
owl:Class.skos:definition: Presents an account of the outcome based on data about the occurrence of events under specified (e.g., experimental) conditions. Statistical explanations refer to numerical evidence on the likelihood of factors or processes influencing the result.
owl:Class.skos:example: Addresses questions of the form, "What percentage of similar patients who received this treatment recovered?"

owl:Class.rdfs:label: System Recommendation
owl:Class.skos:definition: an output of an AI system that stitches together the system's output from tasks and/or includes external knowledge used by the task (s)

owl:Class.dc:description: sequence of underlying system steps and rules that led to a system recommendation
owl:Class.terms:source: Swartout, W. R., & Moore, J. D. (1993). Explanation in second generation expert systems. In Second generation expert systems (pp. 543-585). Springer, Berlin, Heidelberg.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: System Trace

owl:Class.dc:description: Trace based explanations describe the underlying sequence of steps used by the system to arrive at a specific result. They reveal “the line of reasoning per case” (Lim et al., 2009), and “addresses the question of why and how the application did something” (Lim et al., 2009).
owl:Class.terms:source: B. Y. Lim, A. K. Dey, and D. Avrahami, “Why and why not explanations improve the intelligibility of context-aware intelligent systems,” in Proc. of the SIGCHI Conf. on Human Factors in Computing Systems. ACM, 2009, pp. 2119–2128
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Trace Based Explanation
owl:Class.skos:definition: Provides the underlying sequence of steps used by the system to arrive at a specific result, containing the line of reasoning per case and addressing the question of why and how the application did something.
owl:Class.skos:example: Addresses a question of the form, "What steps were taken by the system to generate this recommendation?"

owl:Class.dc:description: any relevant information that can be used to characterize the situation of a user. There are three important aspects of user context: where the user is, whom the user is with, and what resources are nearby.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: User Context

owl:Class.dc:description: a collection of fields that has been gathered for a particular object and the selection is fed to a computer program
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Object Record

owl:Class.dc:description: Scientific explanations reference the results of rigorous scientific methods, such as observations and measurements, to explain something we see in the natural world (Moore, 2000). Adapting from (Miller, 2019), we add that scientific explanations usually contain different components of interacting knowledge, including theories or mechanisms such as physiological ones, which are sets of principles that form building blocks for models; models which represent the relationships between entities and their attributes informed by taxonomies and other classification schemes; and data (e.g. measurements, observations).
owl:Class.terms:source: J. Moore, “Varieties of scientific explanation,” The Behavior Analyst, vol. 23, no. 2, pp. 173–190, 2000.
T. Miller, “Explanation in artificial intelligence: Insights from the social sciences,” Artificial Intelligence, vol. 267, pp. 1–38, 2019.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Scientific Explanation
owl:Class.skos:definition: References the results of rigorous scientific methods, observations, and measurements.
owl:Class.skos:example: Addresses a question of the form, "What is the biological basis for this recommendation?"

owl:Class.rdfs:label: User
owl:Class.skos:definition: the person that receives and ultimately uses the good, service, or technology

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: appetizer
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: a food or drink that stimulates the appetite and is usually served before a meal

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: breakfast
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: the first meal of the day especially when taken in the morning

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: brunch
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: a combination of breakfast and lunch eaten usually during the late morning to early afternoon, generally served from 10am up to 2pm, and regularly has some form of alcoholic drink (most usually champagne or a cocktail) served with it

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: dessert
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: a usually sweet course or dish (as of pastry or ice cream) usually served at the end of a meal

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: dinner
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: the principal meal of the day

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: entree
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: the main course of a meal in the U.S.

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: lunch
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: a usually light, especially one taken in the middle of the day

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: salad
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: a dish consisting of a mixture of small pieces of food, usually vegetables

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: side
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: a food served separately along with the main course

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: snack
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: a light meal : food eaten between regular meals

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: soup
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: a primarily liquid food, generally served warm or hot (but may be cool or cold), that is made by combining ingredients of meat or vegetables with stock, juice, water, or another liquid
